content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Particle <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> moves along the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis so that its position at time <math alttext="t is greater than 0 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="x sub p, end subscript, of t equals, the fraction with numerator e raised to the 2 minus t, power, minus 2 t, and denominator e raised to the 2 minus t, power, plus 3 t, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. A second particle, particle <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, also moves along the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis so that its position at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="x sub Q, end subscript, of t, equals t cubed, minus 3 times t squared, plus 5"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Show that the velocity of particle <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="v sub p, end subscript, of t, equals the fraction with numerator negative 5 times t, times e raised to the 2 minus t, power, minus 5 times e raised to the 2 minus t, power, and denominator open parenthesis, e raised to the 2 minus t, power, plus 3 t, close parenthesis, squared, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>t</mi><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Particle <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> moves along the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis so that its position at time <math alttext="t is greater than 0 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="x sub p, end subscript, of t equals, the fraction with numerator e raised to the 2 minus t, power, minus 2 t, and denominator e raised to the 2 minus t, power, plus 3 t, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. A second particle, particle <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, also moves along the <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis so that its position at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="x sub Q, end subscript, of t, equals t cubed, minus 3 times t squared, plus 5"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Show that the velocity of particle <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="v sub p, end subscript, of t, equals the fraction with numerator negative 5 times t, times e raised to the 2 minus t, power, minus 5 times e raised to the 2 minus t, power, and denominator open parenthesis, e raised to the 2 minus t, power, plus 3 t, close parenthesis, squared, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>t</mi><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) At time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, particle <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at rest. At time <math alttext="t equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is particle <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> moving toward particle <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> or away from particle <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain your reasoning.

(c) The acceleration of particle <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="a, sub Q, end subscript, of t"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find the value of <math alttext="a, sub Q, end subscript, of 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Describe the position of particle <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the position of particle <math alttext="Q"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> approaches infinity. Show the work that leads to your answers.

topic.text: 1.15: Connecting Limits at Infinity and Horizontal Asymptotes

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
